column3: Angela Mayhew, 19, was found dead in the 2600 block of GenesseeStreet.
Shelia Ingold, 36, was found dead in an abandoned van parked inthe 3700 block of Troost Avenue.
Carmeline Hibbs, 30, was found dead in a parking lot at 3560Broadway
Brother, Darryl, is sentenced to life in prison for a drug-relatedmurder
The body of Connie Luther, 29, was discovered in a snowdrift at25th Street and Allen Terrace
Gilyard arrested after his DNA (taken in 1987) was matched withvictim DNA in a national database.
Indicted by the Grand Jury on 12 counts of murder.
Prosecutors file a 13th murder charge against Gilyard for the death inFebruary 1989 of Helga Kruger (26).
Motion made by defense to delay trial until March, 2007.
Convicted of six counts of murder: Barry, Kelly, Barnes, Ford,Ingold, and Hibbs

column1: Applied for job as a cop?

column2: Trash collector at Deffenbaugh Disposal,supervisor for trash collection in Kansas(Disposal Service Deffenbaugh )
Employed as a supervisor at a trash collectioncompany, Deffenbaugh Disposal, since 1986.
Spouse before arrest for the murders
Yes. Rape, the assault of his ex-wife,burglary, a bomb threat, and stealing.

All but one of his victims were prostitutesand/or engaged in that lifestyle with use ofdrugs. The victim who was not a prostitutewas a mentally ill woman in Kansas City whowas known to frequently walk the streets andaccept rides from strangers.

column1: Killer age at start of series

column2: Strangled, most victims had pieces of clothingstuffed in their mouths and ligature marks ontheir necks. Some of the victims were posed.
Prosecutors believe that he drove to the crimescenes

column1: Killing occurred in home of victim?
Killing occurred in home of killer?

column2: Killer brought with him, killer found at scene,no weapon.  Weapons included nylonstockings, shoe strings and wire.

column1: Behavior During Crimes  - All killings involved sexual assault

column2: All but one of killings involved some type ofsexual assault
No, but prosecutors contend that in many ofthe cases Gilyard established contact with thevictims several days before killing them.
Some were bound with  or had something tied
No evidence of this has been found

column1: Left at scene, no attempt to hide

column2: Yes, on the occasions when the body wasposed, bodies found in various places(abandoned van, a field, a parking lot and asnow drift)

The prosecution is seeking the death penalty,the trial is scheduled for October 2006. OnAugust 24, 2006 the defense requested thetrial be postponed until March 2007.  Gilyardis facing ten counts of first-degree murder andtwo counts of capital murder.

The trial was originally scheduled for October2006, however, a motion was made on August24, 2006 to postpone the trial until March 5,2007 due to budget cuts in the state publicdefender system. The motion was granted.Throughout pre-trial hearing attorneys havedebated several issues surrounding the case,including the possibility of eliminating thedeath penalty. A key piece of evidence wasprematurely destroyed by the Kansas CityPolice Department, a blue coat with bloodstains. Because of this the defense hasrequested that the prosecutions death penaltymotion be relinquished. The prosecution isseeking multiple trials with the first one solelyfocusing on five killings that occurredbetween 1986 and 1987.
Gilyard is awaiting trial, trial scheduled for
No, he simply plead not guilty
